diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reactions (e.g., sulfa drugs, anticonvulsants, NSAIDs)
Hemolytic Anemia (as a secondary diagnosis related to immune reactions)
Parvovirus B19 infection (erythema infectiosum or fifth disease)
Connective Tissue Diseases (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Acute Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the glomeruli, which are the parts of the kidney that filter blood. It can lead to symptoms such as pyuria (pus in the urine indicating urinary tract infection) and may contribute to anemia.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and damage to various body parts including joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, heart, and lungs. It may present with erythema (skin rashes), pyuria due to kidney involvement, and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever. Symptoms can include oropharyngeal erythema, erythema on the extremities, and anemia. It might also impact the kidneys, leading to pyuria.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: An infection that can occur in people who have strep throat. It's characterized by a bright red rash on the body, fever, and sore throat. It might show oropharyngeal erythema and can sometimes cause skin peeling on the feet, leading to erythema.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause rash, arthritis, abdominal pain, and kidney involvement. Kidney involvement may lead to pyuria, and the skin presentation can include foot erythema.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: An acute febrile illness of unknown cause that affects the blood vessels throughout the body. It's most common in children and can cause oropharyngeal erythema, a rash on the feet, and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and heart valves. It can cause various symptoms including pyuria due to potential kidney involvement, anemia, and in rare cases, skin erythema.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Foot Infection
diagnoses.description: An infection of the foot that can occur in individuals with diabetes. It may present with foot erythema, and if there's associated kidney involvement or a severe infection, it could lead to pyuria or anemia.

diagnoses.name: Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.description: Refers to a range of kidney conditions that involve the glomeruli. Symptoms can include hematuria (blood in urine), which may sometimes be mistaken or accompany pyuria, and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Anemia of Chronic Disease
diagnoses.description: A form of anemia seen in chronic infections, chronic immune activation, and inflammation. While not a direct cause of the symptoms listed, it can be an indirect result of chronic systemic diseases that manifest with symptoms like those described.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Infectious diseases (such as Tuberculosis or Viral infections)
Neoplastic diseases (related to cancer or tumors)
Evans syndrome (Autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenic purpura)
Hepatitis B or C with cryoglobulinemia
Viral infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B/C, Parvovirus B19)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, if not directly related to autoimmune or inflammatory conditions)
Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (as a possible cause for Basophilia)
Hyperthyroidism (related to eye symptoms and possibly basophilia)
Vitamin D Deficiency (indirectly related via immune function affecting sinusitis frequency)
Autoimmune disorders (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Antiphospholipid syndrome)
Endocrine disorders (e.g., Diabetes Mellitus, Thyroid disorders)
Mood disorders (e.g., Major Depressive Disorder, Bipolar Disorder)
Metabolic syndrome (due to its association with chronic conditions and the risk of developing thromboembolic diseases)
Hypersensitivity Syndrome (Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms - DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Viral Upper Respiratory Tract Infection
diagnoses.rationale: Coryza, which refers to cold symptoms, fits squarely within the category of upper respiratory tract infections.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.rationale: Mononucleosis, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, can cause lymphadenitis (swollen lymph nodes), dysgeusia (taste disturbances), and sometimes chest pain due to spleen enlargement.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.rationale: GERD can cause chest pain mimicking cardiac conditions and dysgeusia due to acid reflux.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Cushing's syndrome can manifest with striae (stretch marks), and while less common, can also associate with systemic symptoms like fatigue which might indirectly influence taste perception.

diagnoses.name: Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Some connective tissue diseases, such as lupus, can cause lymphadenitis and chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Lyme disease can initially present with lymphadenitis, and later stages can involve neurological symptoms that might include dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Costochondritis
diagnoses.rationale: Costochondritis is an inflammation of the rib cage that can cause chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Anxiety can sometimes manifest physically, causing symptoms like chest pain and potentially affecting taste senses due to stress-related changes in saliva production.

diagnoses.name: COVID-19
diagnoses.rationale: COVID-19 has been known to cause dysgeusia, chest pain, and other systemic symptoms including lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Pleurisy
diagnoses.rationale: Pleurisy involves inflammation of the tissues that line the lungs and chest cavity, resulting in chest pain.

diagnoses: Gastrointestinal Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Celiac Disease)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Otitis Media
diagnoses.description: A persistent infection or inflammation of the middle ear, commonly presenting with ear pain, reduced hearing, and sometimes discharge.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. Women with PCOS may have infrequent or prolonged menstrual periods or excess male hormone (androgen) levels.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that affect the thyroid gland, which regulates numerous metabolic processes throughout the body. Disorders include hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, thyroiditis, and goiter.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: The gradual loss of kidney function over time. It can cause a wide range of symptoms including fluid retention, fatigue, and waste accumulation in the body.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing symptoms like weight loss, bloating, and diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth, but can also cause fatigue and joint pain. Can be associated with other autoimmune disorders.

diagnoses.name: Von Hippel-Lindau Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic multi-system disorder characterized by the growth of tumors in the brain, spinal cord, kidneys, and eyes. Angiomatosis is a notable feature.

diagnoses.name: Sturge-Weber Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder indicated by a congenital facial birthmark and neurological abnormalities. Often associated with angiomatous lesions but less likely paired with the symptoms listed.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
diagnoses.description: An inherited disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation in the skin, mucous membranes, and often in organs such as the lungs, liver, and brain.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.description: A term for two conditions (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis) characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, leading to weight loss and various other symptoms.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Asthma (in the context of an asthmatic reaction)
Rosacea (for flushing and conjunctival injection, less likely for the rest)
Medication Side Effects (various medications can induce these symptoms)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Primary angiitis of the central nervous system

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the myelin, which covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant).

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraine is a neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a ministroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: Myasthenia gravis is characterized by weakness and rapid fatigue of any of the muscles under your voluntary control. It's caused by a breakdown in the normal communication between nerves and muscles.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: GERD is a chronic digestive disease. GERD occurs when stomach acid or, occasionally, stomach content, flows back into your food pipe (esophagus). The backwash (reflux) irritates the lining of your esophagus and causes GERD.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection. Brain abscesses can cause symptoms similar to stroke, including problems with speech, vision, and movement.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (such as Epstein-Barr Virus or Cytomegalovirus)
Viral Infections (such as HIV, Hepatitis C)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Vasculitis secondary to infections or medications
Rheumatoid Arthritis (with neurological and renal involvement)
